channel.title: miljko tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from miljko.

item.description: @NahanniFinanci1 @nntaleb @GGCanto Sounds like a good reason to petition for more lanes! (but I imagine an e-bike would be a hazard in that environment‚Ä¶)

@eliowa Excellent point. Another one is: how does this compare to other viruses? SARS-CoV-1? Endemic coronaviruses? Adeno or rhinoviruses? EBV? There is so much opportunity here to learn about viral effects and prevention in general that we are missing because of hyperfocus on covid.

@nntaleb @GGCanto Yep, bike lanes are still key, with or without pedal assist. DC has smartly put them in quieter side streets. That way you only need to worry about drunk restaurant patrons, not so much cars. https://t.co/EcIFZ86LbF

Here is another example of problems with large scale for #RWRI17. ‚ÄúScholars in fields where many papers are published annually face difficulty getting published, read, and cited unless their work references already widely cited articles.‚Äù -> the field stagnates. https://t.co/EQuGVPH64g
From the thread‚Ä¶ May be the reason why @DrCirillo and @nntaleb had to publish their their paper titled "Tail risks of contagious diseases" in Nature *Physics* https://t.co/5mCs3U5HYs
Of course, this wouldn‚Äôt be that big of an issue if we could reliably tell /which/ 25% were ‚Äúreal‚Äù #RWRI17 https://t.co/Uwz66DPYFH
@barttels2 The difference is that good EMRs are rare, but do exist.

Hypothesis: the ability for patients to freely communicate with their physicians via an EMR messaging system is a scam perpetrated upon both, one that leads to physician burnout and, ultimately, less satisfied patients.
@carefullycnsdrd @nntaleb Meant to ask: layers = scale, or is there a difference?

Hands-down my favorite slide from today, with an interesting observation from @nntaleb: it seemed like more doctors were in Chicago to eat steak than listen to lectures (I assume he had trouble getting a table anywhere) #RWRI17 https://t.co/fnD3uaAeiK
Beauty in information #RWRI17 (high-res versions available here https://t.co/D6RiwQVo70 are even better) https://t.co/mlITIgHN1U

‚Ä¶and I‚Äôve disabled cross-posting from https://t.co/tDHjxHcUAD to here, so if you want to continue seeing sepia-toned book excerpts and random article quotes go to https://t.co/Xs1ykrsGUZ or better yet subscribe to the RSS feed (NetNewsWire is a good ‚Äî and free ‚Äî RSS reader).

‚ÄúLazy columnists rest a sweeping argument about political ideology on a tossed-off missive they heard one random person (not a public figure) utter online.‚Äù Lazy journalism is a dominant negative mutant, destroying any benefit good journalism (like ... https://t.co/5pkvphFXBE
@trishankkarthik @nntaleb They wine and dine, sustaining a few less than mediocre (but ridiculously expensive) DC restaurants.
üìö On regression to the mean in Fooled by Randomness. Beware the uncontrolled phase 2 data, especially ones with surprisingly large effect sizes. https://t.co/Oj7mt4gNKb

CDC community transmission map for the last month. BA.5 was 9.6% on 6/4 and became the dominant strain at 53.5% on 7/2, per https://t.co/ff7GEt7VOj. So, unless the CDC changes category thresholds or adds a purple ‚Äúultra high‚Äù category this won‚Äôt tell us anything about BA.5. https://t.co/H8OKWNjnNl

@tmprowell @trishankkarthik For a while now the likelihood of infection without precautions has been 100%, conditional on not dying of other causes. To be clear, that‚Äôs terrible and was completely avoidable (though hard to say when we crossed the threshold). So in that sense, aren‚Äôt levels more informative?
@tmprowell @trishankkarthik To that effect, here is the time lapse of the past month for covid *transmission* levels. BA.5 didn't become dominant until 7/2 per CDC (https://t.co/ff7GEt7VOj) and was <10% when the time lapse started so how much more information can we get out of transmission alone? https://t.co/royAsX9zbx
@tmprowell @trishankkarthik This is the main source of my confusion. Should we base our choices on what the CDC says or what your original tweet shows? https://t.co/KsjYl9m6iN

@trishankkarthik @EricTopol To be more specific: the claim "reinfections may be more severe" is correct. They *may*. But there is a wide chasm between that statement and claims made in the Forever Plague article, and there is some evidence that refutes those claims that should have been at least mentioned.
@tmprowell Please see my response.

@tmprowell @trishankkarthik Got it! Your tweet was about community levels though, not transmission, which is what got me confused. Apologies for getting that part wrong!!! Still, good practice to have date+source on any graph, for this reason.
@trishankkarthik @EricTopol There is actual evidence against the claim, not just lack of evidence: https://t.co/4XLkEhgkm3
@timtriche That is‚Ä¶ completely bonkers. Again, what are they thinking?

@trishankkarthik The tweet was posted yesterday but shows a CDC community transmission map from a period when transmission was high (note that there is no source or date on the all-red map). The actual community transmission level (2nd screenshot) is generally low.
This tweet needs a disinformation flag the size of a barn. What on Earth are people thinking? *Are* they thinking? https://t.co/GsO6Q6KQWH
